li.a: Geraldyn O. Foster Early Childhood Center

source.p: To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser that supports HTML5 video

li.a: NJ Department of Health COVID-19 Homepage

p.span: This plan has been prepared to meet the educational, nutritional, and related services needs, to the extent possible, of the students attending the Bridgeton Public Schools in the event the Department of Health recommends the closing of Bridgeton’s schools. Implementation of the Plan will be monitored and adjustments will be made if necessary. This Plan will be provided to parents on the district’s website in addition to being sent home with students as part of a packet of information.

The Plan was developed with input from the following: Teachers, Master Teachers, Nurses, School Physician, Board Attorney, Principals, Curriculum Directors, Special Education Director, Supervisors, Assistant Superintendent, Food Services Director, Director of Safety & Security, Director of Grants & Funded Programs, Director of Planning/Research & Evaluation, Director of Human Resources, School Business Administrator, District Technology Director, and Superintendent.

Essential personnel will be required to report to work consistent with collective bargaining agreements. Essential personnel are defined as those employees whose presence is necessary to carry out the functions of the school district. Initially, those employees will include administrators, food services staff, security personnel, drivers, maintenance and custodial staff. This may change as circumstances evolve and district needs change, particularly as it pertains to instructional needs.
Once the Superintendent, or his designee, is notified by the Department of Health of the recommendation that Bridgeton schools should close, the following will occur:

The Superintendent, or designee, will contact the Technology Director who will send a robocall to all parents, employees, and board members notifying them that schools will close, specifying the specific date and duration of closing if it is known at the time. Depending upon the advance notification, a written notice may also be provided to students to take home.
The Superintendent, or designee, will direct Principals to disseminate instructional packets to students that will also contain instructions for how students may obtain lunch and breakfast.
Instructions for parents will be placed on the district website as needed and daily informational robocalls will occur to update parents.
This Plan has given consideration to the following questions and concerns about instruction:
What content and skills will be provided to students?
Will the content include skills and knowledge already taught or will it be practice of skills and review of previously taught knowledge?
How will students with special needs be instructed?
How will bilingual and ESL students receive instruction?
How will the content be delivered to students (electronically, hand-delivered packets, pick-up, etc.)?
To what extent is it possible to use technology for content delivery?
To what extent is the internet available to students?
How many students have computers?
Can “hot spots” be created throughout the city to provide internet capabilities to students?
Do students have computers to access the internet?
Can cell phones be utilized for instructional access?
What courses should be provided?
How will Physical Education be provided?
If packets are utilized, how will they be delivered to students?
How will students’ work be assessed?
How will work in the packet count toward grades, graduation, and awards?
When and how will students receive feedback on their work?
How will students in crisis be served?
How will students receiving counseling (group, individual) be served?
To what extent can other subject areas(Art, music) be integrated?
Is the plan compliant with the labor agreements of all impacted employees?

Packets of assignments planned for a two-week period will be provided to students to take home on the day before school is closed. An additional “follow-up packet” of assignments planned for a two-week period will be provided if necessary.

The “follow-up packet” will be delivered with food to the food distribution sites. The district’s student database (Genesis) provides the grade-level and address of each student to ensure the appropriate packet goes to the correct site.
Packets will include content in the core subjects: Language Arts, Math, Social Studies, Science, Physical Education/Health.
Packets will contain differentiated assignments based upon students’ regular education, special education, bilingual, and ESL needs.

Packets are being created under the direction of Curriculum & Instruction Directors with guidance from grade-level Teachers, Master Teachers, and Supervisors in all content areas including Special Education and Bi-lingual/ESL.
Rubrics have been created that outline how students will receive credit for all assignments.
Preschool and Kindergarten students will not be required to return their packets for credit. They may do so if they choose.
A Participation Rubric will be used for students in grades 2-12 to credit students for completed assignments.
Due to the enormous amount of printing required, the printing of packets will be outsourced on Friday, March 13, 2020.
PDF’s of all packets will be available on the district’s website. Results of a survey of students conducted by the district revealed the following data:
Total Students: ~6,800
Total Number of Responses: 4401
No Internet : 11%
Internet Capable: 89%
Note: ~2,400 students did not reply which can skew the results.
All packets will be distributed on the same day at each school to ensure continuity.
This Plan has given consideration to the following questions and concerns about nutrition and food services in no order of importance:
What meals are to be served (breakfast, lunch)?
What foods need to be included in a nutritional breakfast and lunch?
How is the food to be packaged?
Where is the food to be prepared?
How many employees are needed to prepare the food?
How will the employees who prepare the food be selected?
How much time is needed to prepare the food?
Is the plan consistent with the employees’ labor agreement?
How are students to access the food?
Will the food be delivered? If so, how?
Where will students access the food?
What sites are available to the district, in addition to schools, that might facilitate students’ access to the food?
Might the district’s summer feeding program be used as a model for this plan?
Is security needed at delivery sites?
What supervisory staff is needed at the food preparation site and distribution sites?
How do we limit the amount of time students/parents spend at the food pick-up sites?
Are student ID’s required to receive food?
Can parents pick up food for their children?
Will there be written directions and criteria provided to parents?
What time will food be available for pick-up?
The District will implement its Summer Food Services Program which it has operated for years. Meals will comply with the requirements of the United States Department of Agriculture.

Meals will be prepared in and distributed from the Broad Street Elementary School kitchen. Fourteen food service employees are necessary. Four staff members will prepare sandwiches and ten will operate the packing machine.
Three district trucks (two refrigerated, one non-refrigerated) with drivers will be used to deliver the meals to our nine partner distribution sites throughout the community as indicated below:

div.span: (Previously St. Teresa of Avila, Central Ave

p.span: Each meal package will contain a sandwich, fresh or canned fruit, a vegetable, and a bottled water. In addition to the lunch component, cereal and milk will be provided to students for breakfast the next day.

Meals will be “grab and go” only. Two staff members will be present at each location to distribute the bags to all students age 18 and younger. In addition, a security officer will be present at each site.
Each student must be present to receive a meal. ID’s are not required.
Meals may be obtained from the distribution site closest to the student’s home. The Student DataBase generated by Genesis provides that information to the district for food distribution purposes.
Students who have allergen-specific meals are identified and will be personally notified.
This Plan has given consideration to the following questions and concerns about related services, in no particular order of importance:
What health-related services and information should be provided to students?
Given schools are closed, how might such health services be delivered to students?
How might counseling services be provided to students?
What criteria should be applied to determine if students require regular counseling services?
Who can students call if they have a counseling need?
What community resources can be utilized for psychological and counseling services?
Will there be on-call staff members during school hours to counsel students?
How will counseling be provided to students that are required to have it per their IEP/504?
Can counseling be provided via telephone instead of in-person?
If students are being bullied during the closure, how will school personnel handle the situation and investigation?
If a student calls the counseling hotline and makes suicidal or homicidal statements, what will be the action plan?
Can library services be available to students, and if so, how might they be provided?
Where will nurses be located?
Will medications be distributed and what information should be provided to parents?
How will health-related information be provided to parents?
Can teachers have Brutab solutions in their classrooms? If not one for each room, one for each grade level to share? Limit use with students in the room?
May Nurses meet to develop parent/community education newsletters?

How can Nurse act as the medical resource liaison for parents, students, and staff by connecting them to the appropriate resources, and describing what symptoms to look for and when to go to ER vs. Urgent Care vs. PCP, etc...?

General health-related information will be sent home with students on the day before schools close. The information will include advice (i.e. wash hands, avoid close contact with sick people, etc.) initially provided via letter on March 4, 2020 and on the district’s website.
While nurses are not permitted to provide phone triage, a nurse will be available to provide information

on the district web site NURSE TAB, class Dojo, and Robocalls. A Nurse will provide evidence-based information from the District Medical Director, local and state Health Departments, and the CDC. Parents will be Routed to the Nurse tab on the district website for the most updated information.

Parents will be reminded to administer regular medications at home as they would on any other day off from school. The nurse will be available if the parent needs to come pick-up medication from the nurse's office on the day schools close. A Nurse will encourage parents to get regular refills, rather than wait until they run out of medication.
While the Plan states that students must be present at food distribution sites, parents and students will be told that sick students should not leave their homes.

The district’s Head Nurse is getting quotes for thermometers. This is a major barrier with our population because many families don’t have thermometers so they are unable to monitor children’s health. If purchased, thermometers will be distributed along with food at the food distribution sites with information on how to use them and when to seek medical care.

Accommodations for Speech, Occupational Therapy, and Physical Therapy services for students will be done by increasing their services upon the reopening of school commensurate with the amount of time school is closed.

Special Education Teachers in the Self- Contained and Inclusion Classes will provide packets that include functioning and support leveled materials for their students in order to avoid any possible regression.
Our Severely Cognitively Impaired Students including Medically Fragile Students will receive 10 hours of home instruction if and when feasible in addition to the packet received.

Special Education students who require counseling may receive additional counseling and or social skills guidance via telephone with the School Psychologists and the School Social Workers by calling the district phone number. The Special Education Director will contact each student’s parents via robocall and provide them with a phone number to contact if needed.
Psychiatrist consultation will be made available when needed via telephone.
